recommendations.blurb: More resources curated by Chloé Valdary

recItems.blurb: Steinbeck's magnum opus explores the perennial issues of parental baggage and the enduring tension between fathers and sons. Over the course of the story, the protagonist must learn to make peace with his imperfections and internalize the reality that although he can't be perfect, he can be good, and that this is what counts in the final analysis.
recItems.headline: *East of Eden*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: In this collection of essays and interviews, the quintessential American author teaches his audience that the role and obligation of the artist is that of the hero: to take the chaos of life and transform it into meaning and imbue human beings with the power to rise to their higher selves.
recItems.headline: *Shadow and Act*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Ralph Ellison
Penguin Random House LLC, 1964

recItems.blurb: An analysis of the history of the world through the lens of art and that alone should make you want to read it. Everything is either Dionysian or Apollonian or a combination of both. Seriously. Prepare yourselves. You will never see the world in the same way ever again.
recItems.headline: *Sexual Personae: Art and Decadence from Nefertiti to Emily Dickinson*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: Learn about the humility and excellence of Abraham Lincoln, by exploring his sorrow-laden upbringing, his good-natured humor and his radical approach to leadership that led him to hire of some of his most fierce rivals.
recItems.headline: *Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Doris Kearns Goodwin
Simon and Schuster, 2005

recItems.blurb: This philosophical analysis of the book of Genesis makes for great storytelling and offers a new twist to understanding the dynamic, rich inner lives of the Hebrew patriarchs and matriarchs of the Bible.
recItems.headline: *The Beginning of Wisdom: Reading Genesis*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Leon Kass
University of Chicago Press, 2006

recItems.blurb: Israel's national poet writes an autobiography that is such a page turner, you might mistake it for fiction. Ever the consummate humanist, Oz's origin story depicts the rich, turmoil-filled inner lives of Jews and Arabs in a post-WWII Jerusalem and introduces his reader to the tragic yet glorious birth of the modern state of Israel.
recItems.headline: *A Tale of Love and Darkness*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

takeAction.blurb: **Enroll** in a course on the theory of enchantment.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Chloé Valdary developed "The Theory of Enchantment," a social emotional learning (SEL) program that helps educators transform their students' lives.
nodes.whyListen:
After spending a year as a Bartley fellow at the Wall Street Journal, Chloé Valdary developed "The Theory of Enchantment," an innovative framework for social emotional learning (SEL), character development and interpersonal growth that uses pop culture as an educational tool in the classroom and beyond.

Valdary has trained around the world, including in South Africa, The Netherlands, Germany and Israel. Her clients have included high school and college students, government agencies, business teams and others. She has lectured in universities across America, including Harvard and Georgetown. Her work has been covered in Psychology Today Magazine and her writings have appeared in the New York Times and Wall Street Journal.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Corey Hajim curates world-changing ideas from the brightest and boldest minds in business.
nodes.whyListen:
Corey Hajim has spent her career both working in and writing about business. As TED's business curator, Hajim seeks ideas from industry leaders, entrepreneurs, economists and teachers of the trade, ultimately helping speakers shape and share their ideas with the TED audience. 

Prior to TED, Hajim spent a decade in finance, most recently as a portfolio manager and analyst at a hedge fund based in New York, focused on consumer, media and technology equities. Hajim also spent three years as a reporter at Fortune Magazine and her early career working in marketing and project management. She is a graduate of the University of Vermont and earned her MBA at Harvard Business School, where she co-authored case studies with two professors and ran the weekly newspaper, The Harbus. 

Hajim lives in New York City with her husband, three kids, two cats and about a million Lego pieces. Her interests include eating hot food while sitting down, sleeping without interruption and reading books in a cozy chair. Also travel, dance and writing letters.

videoData.description: What does Kendrick Lamar have in common with Disney's "Moana"? They recognize our common humanity and show us how to love ourselves and one another, says writer and educator Chloé Valdary. She shares how she uses pop culture to help people develop resilience and advance social change -- and explains why cultivating love is the key to connection, healing and moving forward together. (This virtual conversation, hosted by TED business curator Corey Hajim, was recorded June 30, 2020.)
